text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The candidate answer explicitly addresses the definition of unreasonableness in private nuisance, stating: \"This is the central question in any nuisance claim. The court does not ask whether the defendant acted unreasonably, but whether the interference with your land is unreasonable.\" It then details the factors used to assess this unreasonableness, which inherently involves balancing the interference against what a reasonable person would tolerate in similar circumstances (locality, time, severity). The discussion of locality (\"What would be a nuisance in Belgrave Square would not necessarily be so in Bermondsey\") directly supports the concept of context-dependent tolerance.", "criterion_id": "917b097d-1675-48db-b174-5360c3fe9aa1"}
